After a considerably long flight, Tucson approaches the area that supposedl=
y Wheelie had taken.  With very little visual data and a short path of left=
 over destruction, Tucson asses his situation and his options.  He knew if =
he remained in beast form maneuvering in this jungle would be next to near =
impossible, especially the way his wings functioned while airborne.  There =
was just no room for large wingspans.  Plus landing on all fours would furt=
her upset the forest floor and the creatures that resided there.  The prese=
nce of a dragon would send the creatures off in a panic.  Out of considerat=
ion for the animals he hovers in mid air while...

" TUCSON MAXIMIZE!"

In =
mid air he transforms into his robot mode and decides to use his skills in =
dexterity and acrobatics, to get to the ground without upsetting anything o=
r anyone.   

Wings fold tightly into his aerodynamic, cylindrical body as =
he now positions himself in a perfect, vertical dive with arms stretched ou=
t in front of him.  He makes an impressive free fall dive maneuver and grac=
efully makes his descent to the ground below.  

As he nears a large tree, =
his outstretched arms allow him to catch a giant branch with both hands as =
he swings off it like a skilled gymnast .  After a spin or two, to build hi=
s momentum, he vaults to a lower branch and continues to do so until he fin=
ally touches down for a flawless landing as he uses his arms for balance.  =
Leaf litter falls in his wake as he first looks around to get his bearings.=
  

Perpetually on the move and constantly busy. 

On Aug 29, 2011, at 4:37=
 PM, Super Cyclonus <supercyclonus@...> wrote:

> The JUNGLE as every=
one pretty much called it was huge! Thousands of
> acres all around with tr=
ees reaching up over one hundred feet into the
> air like tall green spires=
 reaching ever higher into the skies,
> supported by thick powerful trunks =
and supporting power of the
> neighboring trees.
> 
> At first travel was e=
asy as WHEELIE followed a trail of devastation
> and deforestation. It was =
as if a stampede of hundreds of large
> animals fled the jungle, crashing i=
nto trees and stripping foliage as
> they traveled. The result of which was=
 a wide open and relatively
> smooth open path of travel several miles into=
 the immense wooded area.
> But as time passed and the miles built upon the=
mselves the impact of
> the animal's passing become less and less noticeabl=
e, the area itself
> becoming ever darker from the trees high over head and=
 the thick
> growth of brush. The ground was becoming more and more uneven =
as tree
> roots grew into the pathway. What was once a brightly lit area wa=
s now
> much darker, looking like deep evening, even though the noonday sun=

> burned brightly over head, blocked by thge lush canopy of trees, that
> =
only occasionally let in shafts of sunlight light to break open the
> growi=
ng darkness.
> 
> Even the smell of things was beginning to change. The ear=
th smell of
> decomposing leaves and animal waste could be smelled. Not nec=
essarily
> a bad smell, but one that reminded you of the richness of the so=
il
> that was being moved across.
> 
> WHEELIE employing all the skills and=
 experience at his disposal was
> able to make his way in through the uneve=
n and sometimes broken
> ground, the jungle floor was perhaps among the mos=
t inhospitable to
> wheeled vehicles that most of the Earth at this time ha=
d to offer.
> Lattice works of roots and foliage got caught in tires, the b=
rush
> having the annoying habit of blocking sight and hiding nasty ravines=

> and holes and twisted turns. Branches and roots jutted out at strange
> =
angles threatening to stab into more sensative and vulnerable
> undersides =
and tires.
> 
> The sounds of the jungle was all around WHEELIE, animals ch=
attered at
> him from the ground, as others hanging high in the trees looke=
d down
> at the strange orange conveyance that dared travel through demesne=
.
> There were signs of life all around him - The catcalls of other
> anima=
ls, even a few roars in the distance of large predatory beasts.
> Trees and=
 branches moved strangely as if something indiscernible was
> moving among =
them even if the author of the movement could not itself
> be readily seen.=

> 
> Then there was the eerie feeling of being watched. It was a feeling
>=
 that settled upon someone slowly at first. Perhaps a sound that didn=E2=80=
=99t
> repeat itself or a movement than stopped when you did. Maybe it was
=
> just a gut feeling that somewhere out in the density of the foliage,
> in=
 the darkest shadows something was out there, and it was peering at
> you, =
considering you.
> 
> It was into this maze of tree and wood, sounds and sm=
ells that WHEELIE
> was driving, covered in muck and weaving past trees tha=
t were as large
> around as he was long. And yet despite all of that, there=
 was a
> strange sort of barely discernable path that led further and furth=
er
> into the jungle interior, meandering at times and yet always present.
=
> .
> 
> OOC: For anyone that wants to fly in, you will find that you canno=
t
> see the jungle floor, at least the section that Wheelie is in. You can
=
> see the devastation that he followed in, but after a few miles it
> fades=
 and the jungle growth takes over. Any smells or sounds he would
> give off=
 would be muffled by the dense foliage and the ambient sounds
> and smells =
of the jungle. In short he would be nearly impossible to
> find anyone on t=
he forest floor from the air unless you find one of
> the infrequent cleari=
ngs. If you need a more aerial description of the
> place I can describe th=
at in a different post. Just let me know
> 
> (TAG)
